title: Ticket #1292: Calling append_to_list("") on a non-empty MyString still adds a comma
description:
append_to_list("") still adds a comma to a non-empty MyString 
MyString a("ABC");
a.append_to_list("");
a is now "ABC," instead of "ABC"

The unit test output: 

TEST:  Test append_to_list() on a non-empty MyString when passed an empty string
.
INPUT:
    STRING:
EXPECTED OUTPUT:
    RETURN:  ABC
ACTUAL OUTPUT:
    RETURN:  ABC,
RESULT:  FAILURE, test failed at line 2946
remarks:
2010-Mar-23 15:28:59 by adesmet:
I believe the current behavior is correct. I expect a series of calls like 
MyString s = "arg1";
s.append_to_list("");
s.append_to_list("arg3");
to yield a string of "arg1,,arg3".

2010-Mar-23 15:34:09 by psilord:
If this is true, then change the unit tests to test for that behavior and e.emit_comment("We looked at this semantic and expect the result of foo,,bar"); in the unit test, cause we can make arguments each way.

2010-Mar-23 20:18:37 by psilord:
Just so you know, from my review of this work Josh did: 

append_to_list_string_non_empty_empty
append_to_list_mystring_non_empty_empty
    Appending an empty string to a mystring in reality appends a comma to it?
    I'd definitely mark that as a problem, and a probable bug.
    Especially since append_to_list_mystring_empty_empty or
    append_to_list_mystring_empty_non_empty didn't do the same
    behavior with an empty string.

So, the behavior is inconsistent and you're initial intuition might be wrong.

2010-Mar-25 15:47:39 by adesmet:
MyString::append_to_list now treats an argument of "" or NULL as a no-op.

The logic is that we might be appending another MyString "list", and thus an empty string is an empty list. An empty list doesn't need a comma, since it's empty.

Ultimately, this is ambiguous. In the long run code should instead use something like StringList to manage the list, then join the list elements into a single string at the end. Unfortunately StringList itself is flawed enough that we really need a new StringList (probably "class StringList2 : public std::vector<MyString> {... }"). But that's a project for another day.
